91E2280923C748D390ABB173ABEF8AED.description: describe properties of light, and use them to explain naturally occurring optical phenomena (e.g., apparent depth, shimmering, a mirage, a rainbow)

7DFFECD13AB3492282560A21C7CA1E1E.description: identify the factors, in qualitative and quantitative terms, that affect the refraction of light as it passes from one medium to another

C585D017715442E5BC8950A352636892.description: identify ways in which the properties of mirrors and lenses (both converging and diverging) determine their use in optical instruments (e.g., cameras, telescopes, binoculars, microscopes)

3C50176032384911AFFFDF8F6B948115.description: describe the characteristics and positions of images formed by converging lenses (e.g., orientation, size, type), with the aid of ray diagrams

C4E90E05795647D091BA49453CF5E7A8.description: explain the conditions required for partial reflection/refraction and for total internal reflection in lenses, and describe the reflection/ refraction using labelled ray diagrams

49B7A46229194FF08A8D890B22EE4CF9.description: describe, on the basis of observation, the characteristics and positions of images formed by plane and curved mirrors (e.g., location, orientation, size, type), with the aid of ray diagrams and algebraic equations, where appropriate

8643BE9EB22A46B1A750EAEA3AE1EBE8.description: describe and explain various types of light emissions (e.g., chemiluminescence, bioluminescence, incandescence, fluorescence, phosphorescence, triboluminescence; from an electric discharge or light-emitting diode [LED])

D7A839E21F65451099F1FBC41A167A12.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of various characteristics and properties of light, particularly with respect to reflection in mirrors and reflection and refraction in lenses.

CAFC0E4C4D6643958FBB8605E733055F.description: calculate, using the indices of refraction, the velocity of light as it passes through a variety of media, and explain the angles of refraction with reference to the variations in velocity

81510FC14DBE408AB3537A2C0AF207B2.description: predict, using ray diagrams and algebraic equations, the position and characteristics of an image produced by a converging lens, and test their predictions through inquiry

0E5AEF7B28F5471EB8DF29E47FECBD0F.description: use an inquiry process to investigate the refraction of light as it passes through media of different refractive indices, compile data on their findings, and analyse the data to determine if there is a trend (e.g., the amount by which the angle of refraction changes as the angle of incidence increases varies for media of different refractive indices)

2AF2EF2402294B27B5DCE17B244CF32A.description: predict the qualitative characteristics of images formed by plane and curved mirrors (e.g., location, relative distance, orientation, and size in plane mirrors; location, orientation, size, type in curved mirrors), test their predictions through inquiry, and summarize their findings

96C9F8B7F3174193956FACC21906306D.description: use an inquiry process to investigate the laws of reflection, using plane and curved mirrors, and draw ray diagrams to summarize their findings

C33B8D5B4EEA40A288BC821D9319C512.description: use appropriate terminology related to light and optics, including, but not limited to: angle of incidence, angle of reflection, angle of refraction, focal point, luminescence, magnification, mirage, and virtual image [C]

5AA88680C05947FE9A3595343D117B93.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate, through inquiry, the properties of light, and predict its behaviour, particularly with respect to reflection in plane and curved mirrors and refraction in converging lenses;

ED72122ED71540689F63880C1FCB7C99.description: analyse a technological device that uses the properties of light (e.g., microscope, retroreflector, solar oven, camera), and explain how it has enhanced society

C16A90CB798A4729918E1A760E2B3BFF.description: analyse a technological device or procedure related to human perception of light (e.g., eyeglasses, contact lenses, infrared or low light vision sensors, laser surgery), and evaluate its effectiveness

C57251592AA941319B176D8A4098E83B.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: evaluate the effectiveness of technological devices and procedures designed to make use of light, and assess their social benefits;

AE9EBC9ADCE44C4B85A3680229B0E24B.description: identify and describe indicators of global climate change (e.g., changes in: glacial and polar ice, sea levels, wind patterns, global carbon budget assessments)

A60D518324204869A38D6DE36C0F32BF.description: describe, in general terms, the causes and effects of the anthropogenic greenhouse effect, the depletion of stratospheric and tropospheric ozone, and the formation of ground-level ozone and smog

B1298C5023794E298484FC302308BB0E.description: describe how different carbon and nitrogen compounds (e.g., carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide) influence the trapping of heat in the atmosphere and hydrosphere

A80A9E3B15B34FB6AD3061EFDF0C0B1A.description: describe the principal sources and sinks, both natural and/or anthropogenic, of greenhouse gases (e.g., carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, halocarbons, water vapour)

424EB99C7E91422FA04A89EBD32FEEC2.description: identify natural phenomena (e.g., plate tectonics, uplift and weathering, solar radiance, cosmic ray cycles) and human activities (e.g., forest fires, deforestation, the burning of fossil fuels, industrial emissions) known to affect climate, and describe the role of both in Canada's contribution to climate change

E7D7CDEB692B4B68847BD171B61AF61D.description: describe the natural greenhouse effect, explain its importance for life, and distinguish it from the anthropogenic greenhouse effect

CE651779A87146718C504A8B594ACA73.description: describe and explain heat transfer in the hydrosphere and atmosphere and its effects on air and water currents

974D9A3A510148F196F74F2D9E436865.description: describe the principal components of Earth's climate system (e.g., the sun, oceans, and atmosphere; the topography and configuration of land masses) and how the system works

2C267F7B7A7A47B4829A4B72B9185A0C.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of natural and human factors, including the greenhouse effect, that influence Earth's climate and contribute to climate change

DF9E391C307F4B38A233A6B196E5C52D.description: compare different perspectives and/or biases evident in discussions of climate change in scientific and non?scientific media (e.g., with reference to knowledge, beliefs, and values)

0D3E77953C28428EB579C22FE403322F.description: classify the climate of their local region using various tools or systems (e.g., Ecoregions of Canada, bioclimate profiles), and compare their region to other regions in Ontario, Canada, and the world

A5BBD8415518467397E1C5C5E3E5371B.description: investigate, through research or simulations, the influence of ocean currents on local and global heat transfer and precipitation patterns

E27591AB7CDA45EC972C69783325C24F.description: investigate, through laboratory inquiry or simulations, how water in its various states influences climate patterns (e.g., water bodies moderate climate, water vapour is a greenhouse gas, ice increases the albedo of Earth's surface)

0ADE412323024FB4AD2585BC58A29F2F.description: investigate, through laboratory inquiry or simulations, the effects of heat transfer within the hydrosphere and atmosphere

B3426A791FCE445F9B5EB711713850B6.description: investigate a popular hypothesis on a causeand-effect relationship having to do with climate change (e.g., the combustion of fossil fuels is responsible for rising global temperatures; the concentration of atmospheric CO2 is responsible for rising global temperatures; global temperatures have been on the increase since the industrial revolution; the severity of cyclones, hurricanes, and tornadoes increases as atmospheric temperatures increase), using simulations and/or time-trend data that model climate profiles (e.g., data from Statistics Canada and Environment Canada)

C88A3D377FB64509B878FEB03002E54D.description: analyse different sources of scientific data (e.g., lake cores, tree rings, fossils and preserved organisms, ice cores) for evidence of natural climate change and climate change influenced by human activity

B210D1694FBC402AA5B7940F084975A1.description: design and build a model to illustrate the natural greenhouse effect, and use the model to explain the anthropogenic greenhouse effect

0CAAC681F3D648D1B57EC5060EE66775.description: use appropriate terminology related to climate change, including, but not limited to: albedo, anthropogenic, atmosphere, cycles, heat sinks, and hydrosphere

C08660DA12B245E889D5E349308C3F7F.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate various natural and human factors that influence Earth's climate and climate change;

2B85476E28274780AE25837AC091A60B.description: assess, on the basis of research, the effectiveness of some current individual, regional, national, or international initiatives that address the issue of climate change (e.g., Drive Clean, ENERGY STAR, federal and provincial government rebates for retrofitting older buildings to be more energy efficient, carbon offset programs, community tree-planting programs, municipal recycling programs, Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change [IPCC]), and propose a further course of action related to one of these initiatives

C046488E56414838B49811931624156C.description: analyse current and/or potential effects, both positive and negative, of climate change on human activity and natural systems (e.g., loss of habitat for Arctic mammals such as polar bears and loss of traditional lifestyles for Inuit as Arctic ice shrinks; famine as arable land is lost to desertification; an increase in water-borne disease and human resettlement as coastal lands are flooded; expansion of the growing season in some regions)

AD9EA160D0644438A2F854514EA691CF.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse some of the effects of climate change around the world, and assess the effectiveness of initiatives that attempt to address the issue of climate change;

62CFB1EB1C984AAE9384E8AC2E2F846A.description: Earth and Space Science: Climate Change

29CF36B112B3462FBF519BBBD63F1CFC.description: identify simple ionic compounds (e.g., NaCl), simple compounds involving polyatomic ions (e.g., KNO3 , NaOH), molecular compounds (e.g., CO2, H2 O, NH3 ), and acids (e.g., HCl(aq), H2 SO4 (aq)), using the periodic table and a list of the most common polyatomic ions (e.g., OH2 , SO 4 -2), and write the formulae

01304DC55F31416AB08D3B4D13691266.description: describe how the pH scale is used to classify solutions as acidic, basic, or neutral (e.g., a solution with a pH of 1 is highly acidic; a solution with a pH of 7 is neutral)

DD7BBB56194545F3B5E03CCF37851F46.description: describe the process of acid-base neutralization (i.e., an acid reacts with a base to form a salt and often water

3F6FBB04D46144C397CEA643A48EA926.description: describe, on the basis of observation, the reactants in and products of a variety of chemical reactions, including synthesis, decomposition, and displacement reactions (e.g., reactions occurring when magnesium burns or in the production of oxygen from hydrogen peroxide; the reaction of iron and copper sulphate; reactions occurring when fossil fuels burn)

D4737227232A4371A28DF82858A1818E.description: write word equations and balanced chemical equations for simple chemical reactions (e.g., 2H2 + O2 ? 2H2O)

11F6F1A6C0704129A27EDED0B5730C20.description: describe the types of evidence that indicate chemical change (e.g., changes in colour, the production of a gas, the formation of a precipitate, the production or absorption of heat, the production of light)

F3F42C29B0514E1C8B28FF926600F02A.description: explain, using the law of conservation of mass and atomic theory, the rationale for balancing chemical equations

7334E0E791014B14A63CF4488AD68911.description: describe the relationships between chemical formulae, composition, and names of binary compounds (e.g., carbon dioxide, CO2 , has two oxygen atoms and one carbon atom)

F0D4562EA8AF4BCE9C390339BCD013FF.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the general principles of chemical reactions, and various ways to represent them.

1E70E6743A404AF0839E92E2F57AB4CB.description: plan and conduct an inquiry to classify some common substances as acidic, basic, or neutral (e.g., use acid-base indicators or pH test strips to classify common household substances)

865D413DFA944BE7B6E991474272776C.description: plan and conduct an inquiry to identify the evidence of chemical change (e.g., the formation of a gas or precipitate, a change in colour or odour, a change in temperature)

99FD24284C874984A9EC0921857B9B05.description: use an inquiry process to investigate the law of conservation of mass in a chemical reaction (e.g., compare the values before and after the reaction), and account for any discrepancies

34C8DF2457A645A4A56DF60F60DDA94E.description: investigate simple chemical reactions, including synthesis, decomposition, and displacement reactions, and represent them using a variety of formats (e.g., molecular models, word equations, balanced chemical equations) ]

2DFF1DDB945F4270911840D951EC1ECC.description: construct molecular models to illustrate the structure of molecules in simple chemical reactions (e.g., C + O2 ? CO2 ; 2H2 + O2 ? 2H2 O), and produce diagrams of these models

DC3D5A13B84E430AA2D3D4091BD97FF4.description: use appropriate terminology related to chemical reactions, including, but not limited to: compounds, product, and reactant

CC9D834BECE14EE2B4F8D32EF053730C.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate, through inquiry, the characteristics of chemical reactions;

F512F601F45A419CBF342AB5C44CD315.description: analyse how an understanding of the properties of chemical substances and their reactions can be applied to solve environmental challenges (e.g., renewing the Great Lakes, neutralizing acid spills, scrubbing smokestack emissions)

B7B108BFF0CC498E8D68A93BA20E5334.description: analyse, on the basis of research, various safety and environmental issues associated with chemical reactions and their reactants and/or product(s) (e.g., chemical reactions related to the use of cyanide in gold mining, the corrosion of metal supports on bridges, the use of different antibacterial agents such as chlorine and bromine in recreational pools)

A0066D05DFCB4D26B871F8E59FE0FFFA.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse a variety of safety and environmental issues associated with chemical reactions, including the ways in which chemical reactions can be applied to address environmental challenges;

72E4B1FF5E0F427FBDC35F59573F47BF.description: explain the interaction of different systems within an organism (e.g., the respiratory system brings oxygen into the body, and the circulatory system transports the oxygen to cells) and why such interactions are necessary for the organism's survival

01DF12002A064216B8C7BAB83396CB44.description: explain the primary functions of a variety of systems in animals (e.g., the circulatory system transports materials through the organism; the respiratory system supplies oxygen to and removes carbon dioxide from the body)

8735BF095E7443CCB455ACF2B0ACE9B7.description: explain the links between specialized cells, tissues, organs, and systems in plants and animals (e.g., muscle cells and nerve cells form the tissue found in the heart, which is a component of the circulatory system; granum and thylakoid structures act as solar collectors in the chloroplast to produce carbohydrates for plant growth)

E87F7E4564AA483CB0DA7C64F31EA6E5.description: explain the importance of cell division and cell specialization in generating new tissues and organs (e.g., the division of stem cells into specialized cells such as muscle cells or nerve cells in humans; the division of meristematic cells to expand and differentiate plant tissue)

E2DE3DD44D3A4F46AFC839D89C3C6657.description: describe the cell cycle in plants and animals, and explain the importance of mitosis for the growth of cells and repair of tissues

75D742B9B2E94543909FE4C954FDBF0A.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the hierarchical organization of cells, from tissues, to organs, to systems in animals and plants

926F3A1994914D33A93A735BB73E6485.description: use a research process to investigate a disease or abnormality related to tissues, organs, or systems of humans or plants (e.g., heart disease, tobacco mosaic virus, wheat rust)

0C86DCBBCC3A47E2ACAF89D6D2B4CCB4.description: investigate, through a laboratory or computersimulated dissection of a plant, worm, fish, or frog, the interrelationships between organ systems of a plant or an animal (e.g., between the root system and leaf system in a plant; between the digestive system and circulatory system in an animal)

ACDBA5E9663A481CBD11EA96C488BD76.description: investigate the rate of cell division in cancerous and non-cancerous cells, using pictures, videos, or images, and predict the impact of this rate of cell division on an organism

D081DDF1E0094A578B448B407284B241.description: investigate, using a microscope or similar instrument, specialized cells in the human body or in plants, focusing on different types of cells (e.g., bone, muscle, leaf, root cells), and draw labelled biological diagrams to show the cells' structural differences

02186118D2FE463DA9DDA1FCAE50E03D.description: examine different plant and animal cells (e.g., cheek cells, onion cells) under a microscope or similar instrument, and draw labelled biological diagrams to show how the cells' organelles differ

00C61D91BCB74FAAAA4F7450DBC116DA.description: examine cells under a microscope or similar instrument to identify the various stages of mitosis in plants and animals

7BE08FA41EDC499E84402431F39C25F4.description: use appropriate terminology related to cells, tissues, organs, and systems of living things, including, but not limited to: absorption, anaphase, capillaries, concentration, differentiation, diffusion, meristematic, mesophyll, phloem, prophase, red blood cells, regeneration, stomate, and xylem

245BAFCB9B3941DD9FA6378952B7DEC6.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate cell division, cell specialization, organs, and systems in animals and plants, using research and inquiry skills, including various laboratory techniques;

5A54FD56F48542F5B38E0A4E5F572A41.description: describe public health strategies related to systems biology (e.g., cancer screening and prevention programs; vaccines against the human papillomavirus [HPV] and measles, mumps, and rubella [MMR]; AIDS education), and assess their impact on society

1C740AD1FD8F4C0DA3D08957BE13027D.description: assess the importance to human health and/or society of medical imaging technologies (e.g., ultrasound, X-rays, computerized axial tomography [CT or CAT] scan, magnetic resonance imaging [MRI], microscopy, biophotonics) used in Canada in diagnosing or treating abnormalities in tissues, organs, and/or systems

25648E28C2F64B988941C9470A184BC3.description: analyse, on the basis of research, ethical issues related to a technological development in the field of systems biology (e.g., cloning, stemcell research, live organ transplants, transgenic transplants), and communicate their findings

BB8B051A3224479EA8D45684BE562662.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: evaluate the importance of medical and other technological developments related to systems biology, and analyse their societal and ethical implications;

5FFCED84139A48E387E7B39428C0C208.description: Biology: Tissues, Organs, and Systems of Living Things

F17B653D2F064678A831F638F0B9E32D.description: identify scientists, including Canadians (e.g., Sheela Basrur, William Richard Peltier, Alice Wilson, Willard Doyle), who have made a contribution to the fields of science under study

2E3BAAB37D534F06A485A0B0EA41D6F0.description: identify and describe a variety of careers related to the fields of science under study (e.g., meteorologist, medical illustrator, geochemist, optical physicist) and the education and training necessary for these careers

13CBF7DF68B7487CB8F9EE702695D6AA.description: Career Exploration: . identify and describe a variety of careers related to the fields of science under study, and identify scientists, including Canadians, who have made contributions to those fields.

75553210A5334F458B4CC098E3559FAB.description: express the results of any calculations involving data accurately and precisely

2692A1F5C657420EA5A421793A68750B.description: use appropriate numeric, symbolic, and graphic modes of representation, and appropriate units of measurement (e.g., SI and imperial units)

257B1AB83D9647EAB2D49101F6BED500.description: communicate ideas, plans, procedures, results, and conclusions orally, in writing, and/or in electronic presentations, using appropriate language and a variety of formats (e.g., data tables, laboratory reports, presentations, debates, simulations, models)

3E7060C017D6435DB38572ACDAB5CA0C.description: draw conclusions based on inquiry results and research findings, and justify their conclusions

EAF97142176A4F91B176DFEEB387804A.description: analyse the information gathered from research sources for reliability and bias

C9377C0C12DC4D11AFF0B9071FAE5185.description: analyse and interpret qualitative and/or quantitative data to determine whether the evidence supports or refutes the initial prediction or hypothesis, identifying possible sources of error, bias, or uncertainty

B147EE11D02C420A90FE111EB968F321.description: select, organize, and record relevant information on research topics from various sources, including electronic, print, and/or human sources (e.g., websites for public health organizations, federal and provincial government publications, reference books, personal interviews), using recommended formats and an accepted form of academic documentation

98FCE098FE984F68A3B9C45FED215783.description: gather data from laboratory and other sources, and organize and record the data using appropriate formats, including tables, flow charts, graphs, and/or diagrams

2FE57046ADA14C01BDA16925E03B4FDB.description: conduct inquiries, controlling some variables, adapting or extending procedures as required, and using standard equipment and materials safely, accurately, and effectively, to collect observations and data

B6FC379F39364654969B5BF789BAF6A6.description: apply knowledge and understanding of safe practices and procedures when planning investigations (e.g., appropriate techniques for handling, storing, and disposing of laboratory materials [following the Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System-WHMIS]; safe operation of optical equipment; safe handling and disposal of biological materials), with the aid of appropriate support materials (e.g., the Reference Manual on the WHMIS website; the Live Safe! Work Smart! website)

7982D121EB79459DA1A662B36158F439.description: identify and locate print, electronic, and human sources that are relevant to research questions

25731D1DFF42485BB6814CED88CC77AC.description: select appropriate instruments (e.g., a microscope, laboratory glassware, an optical bench) and materials (e.g., prepared slides, an aquarium, lenses, pH paper) for particular inquiries

61E0C465E9594BA68AED29D9A6305351.description: formulate scientific questions about observed relationships, ideas, problems, and/or issues, make predictions, and/or formulate hypotheses to focus inquiries or research

29ADD86EBD314C7C90635B04A307B8FF.description: Scientific Investigation Skills: demonstrate scientific investigation skills (related to both inquiry and research) in the four areas of skills (initiating and planning, performing and recording, analysing and interpreting, and communicating)

A143D9246F9A4E14B63902EC67C5A224.description: Scientific Investigation Skills and Career Exploration
